title: My father is being sued by Nelson & Kennard for an old Capital One cc debt.
question: My father and mother's only source of income is ss retirement and they have no assets or any other source of income. What would happen if there is a default judgment? I understand that ss income cannot be garnished, but they have nothing else to be garnished or taken away.
answers: Answering your question, if there is a default judgment, that means the next step for the Plaintiff/Creditor is to request to have judgment entered, and make a prove up of how much your father owes, and try to collect on the resulting judgment. Consult an attorney in determining whether a collection is likely to be successful, etc.

You / your parents should talk with a debt collection defense attorney. There may be defenses to the lawsuit. If the debt buyer sues, and does not win, the plaintiff may be responsible for your side's attorney's fees. In addition, there may be violations of the FDCPA, which may entitle your parents to money as well as attorney's fees. At the very least, an attorney can tell you what not to say in court,, as well as give specific legal advise.

As far as going to court, the debt collector has the burden of producing witnesses and properly authenticated documentary evidence. Their attorney cannot just stand in front of the judge and say that the defendant owes the money.

"Old" is an important word that nobody seems to have put at the top of their answer.

If it's perhaps as young as three years old it may be past the applicable statute of limitations. A case called "Pincus" here in Florida found that Virginia's three year statute applied to Cap 1 credit cards.

Be sure to make sure that the statute of limitations affirmative defense is claimed if applicable.

If they have no assets and their only source of income is social security then they could judgment proof. Assuming that the creditor obtain a default judgment, that creditor would have little recourse to collect on the judgment. The debt collector would have a judgment but no real ability to collect on the judgment using the normal processes such as wage garnishment, bank levy or judicial lien (assuming he has no home).

You can write the creditor a letter informing them that the debtor is judgment proof. Many attorneys will also write letters to the creditors advising the creditor of this and directing that any future communication be sent to their office.

Make sure that your father does not commingle his social security income with any other income to avoid any issues with identification of the income as social security. Below I have placed a link that describes what it means to be judgment proof.

Once they have the judgment, the next step is trying to collect. You are correct that the SS retirement cannot be garnished it is exempt from collection. The creditor will probably use discovery tools to see if there is something else, not exempt, which can be liquidated. If not, the judgment is probably of no value. To be sure you understand his rights, you can contact a consumer attorney in your area and review all of the facts.

You and your parents should strongly consider contacting an attorney to assist with the collection litigation. If you contact an attorney who is familiar with the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act and the Rosenthal Act, they can review the collection history of the account and analyze whether the collection agency / attorneys may have violated the collection laws. If any such violations are identified, you will have additional leverage to negotiate a resolution to the collection action.

Also, consulting with an attorney might help identify defenses to the collection action that you might not have thought about.

Regardless of whether you consult with an attorney, be sure to file a response to the complaint. If you respond to the complaint, you keep your resolution options open. If you fail to respond, the other side may seek a default.
